we've tried various solutions to this we have encrypted disks which certainly help but there's a wide range of

authentication to the desktop itself can now include MFA so when you think about

desktops when you get into that you have access to a wide range of apps and data on that
physical device now of course we go further when we actually let folks
attach to the network so most people when you're using a VPN you're gonna put in a some sort of third factor so you're
gonna have username password and a multi-factor authentication token or some sort of third factor auth but
that's only gating access into the corporate network what we do in the workspaces environment if you enable MFA
is that actually gates access into the desktop itself so that is you can't connect to the desktop unless you're
using MFA in that sense that means username and some sort of third token when you're logging in and so if you
look at a very big distinction in that you then don't have that apps and data access without that MFA componentry and
then lastly is segmenting policies between client devices and Amazon
workspaces now this gets a little bit nuanced but with traditional
environments that you have to provide to your end-users the end-user expectation is that they can do a wide range of
personal activities on their corporate devices now you may not think that's the
case but if you think about what users want they want to be able to go and browse the web they want to use reddit

they can get pretty pretty angry if they begin to have those capabilities curtailed right and so the belief is

that are a trusted device behavior that's obviously a risk factor so it
means when they're going out and they're hitting web sites and getting content they're getting exposure to threat vectors that you would rather not have
for a device that you're trusting in some fashion so if you're using a cloud desktop you're using Amazon workspaces

work device it is the place where you're doing the work for your business the

so the second area I wanted to dive into is moving the security perimeter to the B PC so today when you build out sites

that works base in so active directory access from the cloud for workspaces can

Directory so that's what we call an ad connector that connects back in so when you launch a workspace you're gonna pick

when that happens each of those directories is then associated with a V PC and so every individual workspace
winds up being part of a directory or part of it and part of the V PC and those directories and V pcs are the

directory the workspaces product itself is built on the idea of fer of full segmentation down through the virtual
machine layer so every workspace is a full virtual machine so effectively
think of this like ec2 instances so there are approaches that are not like this we could have done something called
shared session where you actually have more than one instance running on a single operating system instance so for
example running on running multiple users on a single windows instance that's not what we do here everything is
full virtual machine full segmentation so we rely at the hypervisor layer for the segmentation for workspaces so it
means that you've got 100% certainty that there's no possible cross-pollination no possible way that
data is getting back and forth between those instances in addition to that when you're using the bring your own license
